metadata.author: Neeloffer Mookherjee, Marilyn A. Anderson, Henk P. Haagsman, Donald J. Davidson
metadata.title: Antimicrobial host defence peptides: functions and clinical potential
metadata.abstract: Cationic host defence peptides (CHDP), also known as antimicrobial peptides, are naturally occurring peptides that can combat infections through their direct microbicidal properties and/or by influencing the host’s immune responses. The unique ability of CHDP to control infections as well as resolve harmful inflammation has generated interest in harnessing the properties of these peptides to develop new therapies for infectious diseases, chronic inflammatory disorders and wound healing. Various strategies have been used to design synthetic optimized peptides, with negligible toxicity. Here, we focus on the progress made in understanding the scope of functions of CHDP and the emerging potential clinical applications of CHDP-based therapies.

introduction: Cationic host defence peptides (CHDP), also known as antimicrobial peptides, are naturally occurring peptides that can combat infections through their direct microbicidal properties and/or by influencing the host’s immune responses. The unique ability of CHDP to control infections as well as resolve harmful inflammation has generated interest in harnessing the properties of these peptides to develop new therapies for infectious diseases, chronic inflammatory disorders and wound healing. Various strategies have been used to design synthetic optimized peptides, with negligible toxicity. Here, we focus on the progress made in understanding the scope of functions of CHDP and the emerging potential clinical applications of CHDP-based therapies.

Molhoek, E. M. et al Structure-function relationship of the human antimicrobial peptide LL-37 and LL-37 fragments in the modulation of TLR responses. Biol. Chem.[390, 295–303] (2009). The first study to interrogate the sequence–function relationship in the immunomodulatory functions of CHDP.

Abstract: Cationic host defence peptides (CHDP), also known as antimicrobial peptides, are naturally occurring peptides that can combat infections through their direct microbicidal properties and/or by influencing the host’s immune responses. The unique ability of CHDP to control infections as well as resolve harmful inflammation has generated interest in harnessing the properties of these peptides to develop new therapies for infectious diseases, chronic inflammatory disorders and wound healing. Various strategies have been used to design synthetic optimized peptides, with negligible toxicity. Here, we focus on the progress made in understanding the scope of functions of CHDP and the emerging potential clinical applications of CHDP-based therapies.

Molhoek, E. M. et al Structure-function relationship of the human antimicrobial peptide LL-37 and LL-37 fragments in the modulation of TLR responses. Biol. Chem.[390, 295–303] (2009). The first study to interrogate the sequence–function relationship in the immunomodulatory functions of CHDP.
Competing interests: N.M. is listed as an inventor on patents related to immunomodulatory aspects of host defence peptides and IDR peptides. M.A.A. is Chief Scientific Officer and Director of the start-up company Hexima, which has a cationic antimicrobial peptide in clinical trials for treatment of onychomycosis. H.P.H. owns stock in the start-up company Celestial Therapeutics Inc. and has patents on antimicrobial peptide therapeutics licensed to Zoetis. D.J.D. declares no conflict of interest.
Additional information: Springer Nature remains neutral with regard to jurisdictional claims in published maps and institutional affiliations.
Host defence peptides: Naturally occurring typically amphipathic cationic peptides that modulate host immune responses to control infection and regulate inflammation (commonly used as an alternative name for antimicrobial peptides to encompass all their functions).

summary: Cationic host defence peptides (CHDP), known as antimicrobial peptides, are naturally occurring peptides that can combat infections through their direct microbicidal properties and/or by influencing the host’s immune responses.

The unique ability of CHDP to control infections as well as resolve harmful inflammation has generated interest in harnessing the properties of these peptides to develop new therapies for infectious diseases, chronic inflammatory disorders and wound healing.
Various strategies have been used to design synthetic optimized peptides, with negligible toxicity.
The authors focus on the progress made in understanding the scope of functions of CHDP and the emerging potential clinical applications of CHDP-based therapies.
M. et al Structure-function relationship of the human antimicrobial peptide LL-37 and LL-37 fragments in the modulation of TLR responses.
The first study to interrogate the sequence–function relationship in the immunomodulatory functions of CHDP.
N.M. is listed as an inventor on patents related to immunomodulatory aspects of host defence peptides and IDR peptides.
M.A.A. is Chief Scientific Officer and Director of the start-up company Hexima, which has a cationic antimicrobial peptide in clinical trials for treatment of onychomycosis.
H.P.H. owns stock in the start-up company Celestial Therapeutics Inc. and has patents on antimicrobial peptide therapeutics licensed to Zoetis.
D.J.D. declares no conflict of interest.
Springer Nature remains neutral with regard to jurisdictional claims in published maps and institutional affiliations.

Introduction: Cationic host defence peptides (CHDP), known as antimicrobial peptides, are naturally occurring peptides that can combat infections through their direct microbicidal properties and/or by influencing the host’s immune responses.

The unique ability of CHDP to control infections as well as resolve harmful inflammation has generated interest in harnessing the properties of these peptides to develop new therapies for infectious diseases, chronic inflammatory disorders and wound healing.
Various strategies have been used to design synthetic optimized peptides, with negligible toxicity.
Results: The authors focus on the progress made in understanding the scope of functions of CHDP and the emerging potential clinical applications of CHDP-based therapies.
M. et al Structure-function relationship of the human antimicrobial peptide LL-37 and LL-37 fragments in the modulation of TLR responses.
The first study to interrogate the sequence–function relationship in the immunomodulatory functions of CHDP.

M.A.A. is Chief Scientific Officer and Director of the start-up company Hexima, which has a cationic antimicrobial peptide in clinical trials for treatment of onychomycosis.
H.P.H. owns stock in the start-up company Celestial Therapeutics Inc. and has patents on antimicrobial peptide therapeutics licensed to Zoetis.

top_statements: Cationic host defence peptides (CHDP), also known as antimicrobial peptides, are naturally occurring peptides that can combat infections through their direct microbicidal properties and/or by influencing the host’s immune responses

We focus on the progress made in understanding the scope of functions of Cationic host defence peptides and the emerging potential clinical applications of Cationic host defence peptides-based therapies
N.M. is listed as an inventor on patents related to immunomodulatory aspects of host defence peptides and IDR peptides
H.P.H. owns stock in the start-up company Celestial Therapeutics Inc. and has patents on antimicrobial peptide therapeutics licensed to Zoetis
